ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar four days a week with one day of virtual discussion assignment

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to recognize a lot more Chinese characters and new sentence structures in addition to a little Chinese culture.
I learned how to read and write Chinese characters really quickly. Each lecture comes with lots of grammar lessons as well.

The ability to give presentations and write essays entirely in Chinese. Speaking precisely, I realized my tones and pronunciation could be improved and has since been corrected. I recognize many more characters and read intermediate level texts.

As a heritage speaker who had never had any formal Chinese education (e.g. Chinese school or Chinese classes) I learned how to approach learning the language. It was a tricky transition at first but Chen laoshi was extremely helpful and understanding.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class sizes are small so I feel like I personally knew everyone in my class, even on Zoom. Classes all seem very repetitive. This repetitiveness is good, but also causes the class to be not that exciting sometimes.

Strengths: bonded with classmates even though it was virtual this year, class was pretty fun because the teachers are pretty chill, Chinese lesson book we used was very helpful 

Weaknesses: at the end of the course everything was pretty rushed and we had to memorize 3x as many characters each chapter than earlier chapters, teachers grade you harsher if you start out with a higher skill (for example, if you speak better than the other students in your class, then you will be graded harsher than the other students and will often get lower grades than them due to nitpickiness because the teacher has higher expectations of you) idk if that made sense but I didn't think it was fair

Strengths: lots of practice reading Chinese, good instructors, opportunities to get help during office hours
Weakness: little or no review sessions for tests, which could be beneficial
Chen laoshi is a great teacher! The homework was definitely doable if you managed your time correctly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The small class sizes were very nice on Zoom (less than 10).
This course was pretty engaging overall.

I think the way that the class was transferred to online learning was very smooth and effective. It was a little bit strange at first with the breakout rooms but I think after the first few classes all the kinks were ironed out and the class was pretty successful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the teachers are all really nice and the workload is manageable especially for 1.5 credits.
Yes, if you are a heritage speaker and you want to be able to read and write basic Chinese

As someone who couldn't have a conversation in Mandarin before, I wasn't sure if I was placed in the right level. I found that sure some of my classmates were a little more fluent, but the class was really good at helping us work on our weaknesses. I can definitely say that after taking this course, my speaking, reading, and writing skills improved a lot in a short time. I'm more confident in speaking, and this course has encouraged me to continue speaking in Chinese whenever the opportunity arises.
Yes, I think it was really helpful in teaching me how to approach learning how to read and write as a heritage speaker.
Yes, this will help you improve your reading and writing skills.
